19. H.R. 19 allows biomedical innovation to continue to thrive. It does not abandon the success of 21st Century Cures. It lowers drug costs for Americans while maintaining access to drugs that exist now and ensuring that access is sustained in the future. #MoreCures

18. H.R. 19 removes uncertainty at the pharmacy counter by requiring insurance companies to provide pricing information to doctors so that patients and their doctors can have discussions about what medicine is best for them before they head to the pharmacy.
17. H.R. 19 increases transparency into patent listings so that manufacturers of generics and biosimilars will have adequate information to enter the market.
16. H.R. 19 helps access to prescription drugs in rural areas by reforming Direct and Indirect Remuneration fees.
15. H.R. 19 cracks down on pharmacy benefit managers by requiring more transparency in reporting of aggregate rebates discounts and other price concessions.
14. H.R. 19 would require pharmaceutical companies to provide pricing information in direct-to-consumer advertisements.
13. H.R. 19 benefits American patients with high medical costs by making permanent a threshold of 7.5 percent of adjusted gross income for purposes of the medical expense tax deduction.
12. H.R. 19 establishes a new negotiator at the United States Trade Representative to ensure that America is not subsidizing the world’s drug costs.
11. H.R. 19 lowers the cost of drug administration by not paying drastically more for the same service when it is provided in hospital or other traditionally more expensive environments.
10. H.R. 19 lowers the cost of insulin by capping insulin costs for seniors in Medicare Part D and incentivizing insurers to cover their fair share of insulin costs.
9. H.R. 19 strengthens transparency and accountability in our existing drug pricing system.

8. H.R. 19 corrects for the increased threshold to reach catastrophic coverage in Medicare Part D which the Democrats have failed to fix. This bill will correct the course by providing seniors with a refund in 2020 for the drug costs they should not have had to incur.
7. H.R. 19 promotes healthy competition for lower cost generics.
6. H.R. 19 includes policies such as CREATES and Pay for Delay to prevent pharmaceutical companies from gaming the system.
5. H.R. 19 saves money for patients and their families not just the government.
4. H.R. 19 will cap out-of-pocket costs in Medicare Part D for our seniors at $3100 per year – ensuring protection from the high cost of prescription drugs.
3. H.R. 19 could pass both chambers of Congress and be signed into law in 2019.
2. H.R. 19 is bipartisan. The bill includes more than 40 bipartisan drug pricing policies many of which have passed through committees in the House and Senate this year.
